Definition of Personal Information (PII): An individual's first name or first initial and last name, in combination with Social Security number, driver’s license or identification card number, or account, credit, or debit card number with security code, access code, or password
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized acquisition of unencrypted computerized data that materially compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information maintained by the information holder
Risk of Harm Analysis: Notification is required only if breach “materially compromises” the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information
Timing: Notification to Individuals: Must be made “immediately,” no later than 45 days from discovery of the breach, unless delayed at the request of law enforcement
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: No general statewide AG notification requirement for private sector breaches; state agencies must notify the Comptroller within 5 working days
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: No explicit requirement unless otherwise applicable under federal law or if over 1,000 persons are affected (per federal guidelines)
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Content must allow individuals to protect themselves; generally includes incident description, type of PII involved, and protective measures being taken
Method of Notice (to Individuals): May be by written, electronic (if consistent with E-SIGN), or substitute notice (email, website, and media) if thresholds met
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Civil lawsuits may be brought for failure to notify within required 45 days; AG enforcement and damages possible
Key Exemptions: Exempt if consistent internal policy meets state law; encrypted data exempt unless key is accessed
Notes / Other Requirements: Public agencies notify Comptroller within 5 business days; written notice required “immediately” and no later than 45 days; law enforcement may delay notice for investigation

Definition of Personal Information (PII): An individual's name (first name or initial and last name) in combination with any of the following: Social Security number; driver’s license or state identification number; or account, credit, or debit card number with any required security code, access code, or password
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized access and acquisition of computerized data that compromises the security or confidentiality of personal information owned or licensed and causes, or is reasonably believed will cause, a material risk of identity theft or fraud to a resident
Risk of Harm Analysis: Notification is not required if the entity reasonably believes the breach has not and will not cause a material risk of identity theft or fraud [risk of harm analysis]
Timing: Notification to Individuals: In the most expedient time possible, but not later than 45 days following discovery of the breach
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: No explicit Attorney General notification requirement; limited requirements for specific industries or under related laws
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: If more than 1,000 Ohio residents are notified, must notify all nationwide consumer reporting agencies without unreasonable delay regarding the timing, distribution, and content of the consumer notice
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Notice must include information to permit individuals to protect themselves; typically includes description of the incident, type of personal information, and steps being taken, but no strict statutory content specified
Method of Notice (to Individuals): Written, telephone, or electronic notice; substitute notice (such as email, website, or published notice) allowed if certain cost or population thresholds are met
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Penalties may be up to $10,000 per day for non-compliance; other civil penalties may apply and AG may bring enforcement action
Key Exemptions: Exemptions include encrypted data (unless the key is obtained); notification not required if the covered entity’s own policy consistent with state law is followed
Notes / Other Requirements: Notification may be delayed if law enforcement determines it would impede a criminal investigation; third-party notice required if covered info maintained for another entity; substitute notice available in specific situations

Definition of Personal Information (PII): Personal information includes an individual's first name (or initial) and last name in combination with Social Security number, driver's license or state ID number, or financial account, credit/debit card number with any security code, access code, or password required for access
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized access and acquisition of unencrypted and unredacted computerized data that compromises the security or confidentiality of personal information, causing or reasonably believed to cause identity theft or other fraud to a resident
Risk of Harm Analysis: Risk of harm analysis: Notification is not required if after reasonable investigation and law enforcement consultation, there is no reasonable likelihood of harm to customers
Timing: Notification to Individuals: Notice to affected individuals must occur without unreasonable delay following the discovery or notification of the breach, except for delay requested by law enforcement for investigation
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: No general requirement to notify Attorney General (AG) for private sector entities; AG notification may be required for violations or enforcement action
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: Must notify nationwide consumer reporting agencies if more than 1,000 West Virginia residents are affected
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Notice must describe the categories of accessed/acquired information, entity contact info, the type(s) of information maintained, whether entity maintained info on the individual, and toll-free contact numbers and agencies for advice on fraud alerts/security freezes
Method of Notice (to Individuals): Notice may be provided by written letter, telephone, or electronic notice; substitute notice (website posting, major media, email) allowed if cost or population thresholds met
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Civil penalties up to $150,000 per breach or series of similar breaches may be imposed by the Attorney General; failure to comply constitutes unfair/deceptive practices
Key Exemptions: Exemptions include good‐faith acquisition by employee/agent for lawful purposes, and encrypted/redacted data (unless key/codes are obtained); safe harbor for entities whose own notification policies are consistent with state law
Notes / Other Requirements: Notification may be delayed at the request of law enforcement; third‐party processors must notify owner; additional requirements for healthcare info under HIPAA may apply

Definition of Personal Information (PII): Personal information includes an individual’s first name (or initial) and last name in combination with one or more of the following: Social Security number; driver’s license or state ID number; or financial account, credit, or debit card number with any security code, access code, or password required to access
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized access and acquisition of unencrypted computer data that compromises the security or confidentiality of personal information and is reasonably believed to have been acquired by an unauthorized person
Risk of Harm Analysis: Notification is required only if the breach is reasonably believed to cause identity theft or other fraud; risk of harm analysis applies
Timing: Notification to Individuals: Must be made as expeditiously as possible and without unreasonable delay, and no later than 45 days from discovery, except as needed for law enforcement investigation or system restoration
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: Attorney General (AG) notification is required for any breach affecting resident(s) of the state, without unreasonable delay
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: If more than 1,000 Virginia residents are notified, must also notify all nationwide consumer reporting agencies without unreasonable delay
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Notice must include general description of the breach, the type of personal information acquired, measures taken to protect against further breaches, and a contact number for further information
Method of Notice (to Individuals): Notice may be provided in writing, by telephone, or electronically (consistent with E-SIGN); substitute notice (email, website, media) is permitted if notification cost exceeds $50,000 or more than 100,000 persons are affected
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Attorney General may impose a civil penalty not to exceed $150,000 per breach; individuals may seek direct economic damages in civil action
Key Exemptions: Exemptions for encrypted data (unless encryption key is accessed); good-faith acquisition by employees or agents for business purposes; safe harbor if entity's own notification policy is consistent with state law
Notes / Other Requirements: Notification may be delayed at law enforcement’s request; third-party processors must notify owner; additional rules for medical/health information under Va. Code 32.1-127.1:05

Statute(s) Citation: Md. Code Ann., Com. Law §§ 14-3501 to 14-3508
Definition of Personal Information (PII): Personal information is an individual's first name or initial and last name in combination with: Social Security number, driver’s license or state ID number, or financial account, credit, or debit card number with any required security or access code
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized acquisition of computerized data that compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information
Risk of Harm Analysis: Risk of harm analysis: Notification is not required if after reasonable investigation, misuse of the information is not reasonably likely
Timing: Notification to Individuals: Notification to individuals must occur as soon as reasonably practicable but no later than 45 days after discovery of a breach
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: Attorney General must be notified prior to notice to individuals if any Maryland resident is notified
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: If more than 1,000 individuals are notified, must also notify nationwide consumer reporting agencies
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Notice to individuals must include a description of the categories of personal information acquired and contact information for the business
Method of Notice (to Individuals): Notice may be provided in writing, electronically (if consistent with E-SIGN), or by telephone; substitute notice allowed if cost or number of affected individuals is high
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Attorney General may bring enforcement actions; civil penalties possible per violation
Key Exemptions: Exemption for encrypted data unless key is accessed; compliance with own consistent policies may provide safe harbor
Notes / Other Requirements: Fines for delayed notice; third-party processors must notify data owners; substitute notice requirements apply

Definition of Personal Information (PII): Personal information means first name or first initial and last name combined with Social Security number, driver’s license or state identification number, or account, credit, or debit card number with any required security or access code
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized acquisition of unencrypted computerized data that compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information
Risk of Harm Analysis: Risk of harm analysis: Notification is not required if, after investigation, the entity determines that the breach is unlikely to result in harm to the individual
Timing: Notification to Individuals: Notice to affected individuals must occur without unreasonable delay but no later than 60 days after determination of a breach
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: Must notify the Attorney General if residents are notified
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: If more than 500 Delaware residents are notified, consumer reporting agencies must be notified
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Notice must include categories of personal information compromised and steps individuals can take for protection
Method of Notice (to Individuals): Notice may be in writing, electronically (if consistent with E-SIGN), or by telephone; substitute notice allowed for large scale or cost
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Attorney General can seek enforcement; penalties may be imposed for non-compliance
Key Exemptions: Exemptions for encrypted or redacted data unless the key is accessed; safe harbor for consistent internal

Definition of Personal Information (PII): Personal information means first name or first initial and last name with: Social Security number, driver’s license or state ID number, or account, credit, or debit card number with any required security or access code
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized access of computerized records that compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information
Risk of Harm Analysis: Notification is not required if misuse is not reasonably possible (risk of harm analysis applies)
Timing: Notification to Individuals: Notice to individuals must be made expediently and without unreasonable delay
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: Attorney General and Division of State Police in the Department of Law and Public Safety must be notified for public entities
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: No explicit requirement for credit agency notification unless federal law applies
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Notice must include description of circumstances of breach and types of data involved, plus advice to monitor and protect credit
Method of Notice (to Individuals): Notice by written letter, electronic notice (consistent with E-SIGN), or substitute notice if large scale or cost is high
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Attorney General can seek penalties for willful failure to provide timely notice
Key Exemptions: Encrypted data is exempt unless the key is accessed; compliant internal policies qualify for safe harbor
Notes / Other Requirements: Breach must be disclosed to third party if data managed on their behalf; law enforcement delay permitted

Definition of Personal Information (PII): Personal information means first name or initial and last name with: Social Security number, driver’s license or state ID number, or financial account, credit, or debit card number with any required security code or access code
Definition of Breach: Unauthorized access and acquisition of unencrypted and unredacted computerized data that is likely to result in a substantial risk of harm or identity theft
Risk of Harm Analysis: Notification is not required if, after a reasonable investigation, misuse is not reasonably likely (risk of harm analysis applies)
Timing: Notification to Individuals: Without unreasonable delay following discovery of the breach
Timing: Notification to Attorney General: If more than 1,000 Pennsylvania residents are notified, must also notify nationwide consumer reporting agencies
Timing: Notification to Credit Agencies: If more than 1,000 persons affected, consumer reporting agencies must be notified
Contents of Notice (to Individuals): Notice must include data types exposed, advisement on protecting accounts, and relevant agency contacts
Method of Notice (to Individuals): Notice in writing, electronically (if consistent with E-SIGN), or by telephone; substitute notice requirements apply
Penalties for Non-Compliance: Attorney General may enforce; civil penalties possible; direct cause of action for damages
Key Exemptions: Exemptions for encrypted or redacted data unless key is accessed; safe harbor if policies meet state law
Notes / Other Requirements: Notice to Attorney General if breach affects more than 500 residents; enforcement and remedies provided
